The grey.Yes....Definitely the grey.Oh, I haven't had a chance to look at that yet, dear.Blot it...Blot it..Wear your scarf. There's a chill out there.I'm fine, thank you Susie.Yes. Frightful.Yes, of course, dear. Today.What are they playing?Silly man.He hasn't got his scarf on.I'll go.I've got a place at Oxford.Mother?What have you got on your head?You look ridiculous.No, Denis, Bosslady no like.Feet.I didn't know that you were dropping by today, dear.Jaqueline...Of course. Yes!I love you so much but...I will never be one of those women Denis - who stays silent and pretty on the arm of her husband. Or remote and alone in the kitchen doing the washing up for that matter.No - one's life must matter, Denis. Mark...You look happy.They grow up so fast.Mark.There they are, my little twins. Mark...You look happy.The right honourable gentleman knows that we have no choice but to shut down the schools!Because his union paymasters have called a strike deliberately to cripple our economy. The only thing you should remember is that everyone else is either reckless or inept. And often both. MARGARET eyes the road, gesturing CAROL to move forward.One must be brave if one is to take the wheel-Move over... Move to your right a little bit...Carol!To the right. Move to the right! A yelp from CAROL as the car swerves a little, narrowly missing a lone CYCLIST-So sorry! Terribly sorry! MARGARET throws a wave from the wound down window. The CYCLIST swerves on recognizing her, watching as the car goes round and round the square, almost balletic.Have you been trying to make breakfast? For Goodness sake, Denis!I've decided. I'm going to run. MARGARET smiles, a growing resolution gripping her.I'm going to run for Leader of the Party. CAROL'S utter disappointment on seeing she has lost MARGARET already.What's she on about?Oh, right. Of course.What I'm saying is that someone must force the point, say the unsayable. None of these men have the guts. MARGARET sees the burnt toast and energetically starts clearing up and putting more bread under the grill.But he's weak, and he's weakened the party. There will be no female Prime Minister here, not in my lifetime. No. And I told Airey, I don't expect to win the leadership, but I am going to run. Just to shake up the party. We are not wrong. May I see it?The wording is sloppy here, and here.I do say so.This is ridiculous. There are two "T's" in "committee"!This is shameful. Shameful! I can't even rely on you for a simple timetable! Are you unwell? Yes you are unwell. Give me the pencil, give it to me!If this is the best you can do I had better send you to hospital, and I shall do your job as well as my own and everyone else's. DENIS, fingers touch hers, she looks at him, sees the tender concern in his eyes. Denis?Denis wait...Where are your shoes? You can't go without shoes! Not yet.Yes...Steady...Steady...Steady the buffs...154d NO...Not yet...Denis. Wait...I 154d said I don't want you to go yet. MARGARET looks around her.I was just going to get dressed.Oh. No, you do it.No, dear, I'll do it.No no. I'm not going anywhere.

JUNE.raw_line: Goodness! There you are. JUNE's look of quiet concern.I don't understand how it happened, how could she possibly have got out? It's very very important -Please just make it really clear. Who's on after you?Beautiful day. Oh, you've made a start. Carol's coming soon, I'll get some bags. ALFRED.raw_line: Did someone cover the butter?Margaret-Good girl.Tomorrow, no matter what they do, it'll be business as usual.What is the life blood of any community? It's business....Not just big business but small businesses, like mine.We on this island are strong. We're self-reliant. Sometimes we're plain bloody minded.But we also believe in helping each other. And I don't mean by state hand-outs...Never run with the crowd, Margaret. Go your own way.Don't let me down Margaret.We on this island are strong. We're self-reliant. Napoleon called us a nation of shopkeepers.He meant it as an insult but to me it's a compliment. That's why he couldn't beat us, and that's why Hitler can't beat us.We Conservatives believe in giving people the freedom and opportunity to fulfil their own potential, especially the young. There's no good in pretending we're all equal, we're not all the same, never have been, never will be. We should encourage our children to aspire to achieve more than we have, for our children today will be the leaders of tomorrow.

CAROL.raw_line: Hello Ma. Bloody taxi driver. Wouldn't take my card. I said don't have a sticker saying you take Visa and then insist on cash. Can you believe it? I was rummaging around the bottom of my bag. He didn't get a tip.Yes, you said yesterday...You wanted to make a start on Dad's things. The cupboards ? Then I can help you dress.You've got Michael and-Coming for dinner tonight.Oh God. Isn't it terrible?They think it's Al Quaida -I'm sure they've already-Now ma, are we going long or just below the knee tonight?I hear you went out today...You mustn't go out on your own Mummy. We've talked about that.Call Robert he'll get it for you if June's not up-No one is saying that.What?It's nearly all familiar faces, William, Michael and his lovely wife-And then there's Peter, James R and James T and that very nice man-- we met last year.I think he's bringing his new lady friend just to mix it up a bit. We're rather short on women - but I'm sure we'll manage-Ma?The bombings, mummy. Today?We were just talking about them?Great to see you, thank you very much for coming.OK...hold on to me...that's right.You've got an eyelash.Make a wish.I spoke to Doctor Michael today-He is very good and very expensive-...I know you're not due to see him for another month but I've spoken to him and he can fit you in tomorrow.Just for a check up. Ma please-Mark?Mark's with Sarah and the children.He's not here Mummy.Mark lives in South Africa......you are not Prime Minister anymore and Dad is...Dad is dead-Righty-ho. Night night Ma. Sleep well.I swear, it's all gone completely out of my head. My driving instructor thinks I should pass but I feel as if I've hardly had any lessons. Ridiculous isn't it? Maybe third time lucky.Right-o.But if I move to the right aren't I on the wrong side of the road?Well he's in the way!Hey, look at me, driving! CAROL's squeals of delight, let loose on the open road. The tyres screech on the corner.Thanks Ma, that was terrific! I really feel I've got a handle on it now.You should have seen us, Pa.Mummy took me for a test drive - We went absolutely everywhere. All over the place -Silly me!All the time I thought I was having a driving lesson, it was all about my mother, just for a change!My God, Mum. Are you alright? Mummy you should have called for help, silly old sausage. Have you not even been in your bed properly? You've done all this?Yes well don't worry about all this. June and I will crack on with it....Shall I call someone, see if anyone can come over and do your hair? MARGARET looks at her warmly.
